Hey everyone,

I'm trying to resolve a convergence error problem.

Here's what I'm trying to do:
-----------------------------

1. I need to solve a system of equations parallel with the zero 
dim. reactor model such that,
I need to correct for some of the species production terms at 
everytime step, and solve for additional
set of variables M0 throuh M5 (y terms) and Q0 through Q5 (ydot 
terms)

2. I created a new class derived from the "Reactor" class and 
reimplemented the virtual methods
	in the original class.

3. In the methods evalEqs and UpdateState, I have inserted my 
variables M0 through M5 in array "y"
and Q0 through Q5 in array "ydot" at positions m_nsp+2.

since y[0] = internal energy
      y[1] = volume
	y[3] - y[m_nsp-1] are species mass fractions
	
Another parallel fortran code, that I call from within C++, gives 
me values of the variables Q's (Q0 through Q5) based on initial 
M's (M0 through M5) values, and hence gives me a new complete data 
set for y and ydot arrays. The integrator then integrates to a new 
y array (that gives me new initial conditions of M's to recompute 
Q's)
that I use to update my older variables in UpdateState method.

I used an instance of this class in a reactor code by using
myclass r;

instead of
Reactor r;

My problem:
-----------

I get an error message as follows:

Procedure: setState_UV
Error: no convergence. dt=nan
tol = 1e-08
u = nan v = 0.439382

I get this message right after the first time step.

My Questions:
-------------

1. Just to begin with, my Q (ydot) terms are not even coupled to 
the ydot[0] that is internal energy
equations. why do I get a convergence error in u, when everything 
else is the same.

2. When I commented out the assignment lines for y and ydot, such 
that I did create space in the array
for my variables, but assigned all of them values of zero, the 
code did work for a while, but looped
endlessly around the ignitor functor peak. I guess, that too had 
to do with convergence problem.
In other words, I could see solutions only until the igniter 
reservoir sent out a pulse of H atoms.
As soon as the temperature pulse began to be sensed in the 
solution, each time-step calculation
became extremely slow.

3. The only other way I could get this code to work, is to leave 
the original y and ydot arrays
as they were and create another integrator, y and ydot arrays to 
solve for my M variables. This might be
way too inefficient, I think. I don't quite see why the approach I 
took isn't working! Would this alternate
approach be a better way of handling the problem?

I can't seem to resolve this problem, and need help with it.

Any help would be appreciated. Please let me know, if the 
information provided doesn't seem adequate or
if any further clarifications are necessary.


Regards,

Bhupinder



--
